Top concerns?

When did these concerns start?
past-year

Triggers?
Divorce or relationship breakup, Loss of loved one, Childhood trauma, Substance use

(502) 555-7823

MEDICATION ALLERGIES

Yes

Medication allergies?

CURRENT MEDICATIONS
Medication name?
Lisinopril

Dosage?
10mg daily

Prescribed for?
High blood pressure

Medication name?
Ibuprofen

Dosage?
800mg as needed

Prescribed for?
Chronic back pain from work injury

PAST PSYCHIATRIC MEDICATIONS
Medication name?
Zoloft (sertraline)

Duration?
6 months

Reason discontinued?
Didn't feel like it was working, stopped on my own

Medication name?
Trazodone

Duration?
3 months

Reason discontinued?
Made me too groggy in the morning, couldn't function at work

MEDICAL CONDITIONS
Conditions you have?
Hypertension, Chronic back pain (work-related injury 2018), Type 2 Diabetes (pre-diabetic, diet controlled)

SAFETY ASSESSMENT
Current suicidal thoughts?
No, but have had thoughts in the past (6 months ago during worst of divorce)

Thoughts of harming others?
No, but struggle with anger sometimes

Specific plan for self-harm?
No

Currently safe?
Yes

Emergency contact available?
Yes - sister Maria is very supportive

Currently in treatment?
No, this is first time seeking help since divorce

HEALTHCARE PROVIDERS
Do you have a primary care provider?
Yes

PCP Name?
Dr. Sarah Chen

PCP Practice?
Owensboro Family Medicine

PCP Phone?
(270) 555-3200

Do you have a therapist/counselor?
No, never been to therapy before

Do you have a psychiatrist?
No

Do you have a substance use disorder provider?
No, but know I need help with drinking

SOCIAL & LIFESTYLE
Current living arrangement?
Living alone in apartment

Housing stability?
Stable for now, but rent is expensive and finances are tight

Relationship status?
Divorced (finalized 8 months ago)

Children?
Two daughters, ages 8 and 11, see them every other weekend

Social support network?
Limited - sister is main support, lost most friends during marriage/divorce

Employment status?
Full-time warehouse supervisor

Employer?
Amazon Fulfillment Center

Highest education completed?
High school diploma, some college (didn't finish)

Financial stress level?
Very high - child support, legal fees from divorce, medical bills from back injury

Military service?
No

Legal issues?
DUI 14 months ago (during separation), completed probation

SUBSTANCE USE
Do you smoke or use tobacco?
Yes, about half pack per day (trying to cut back)

How often do you drink alcohol?
Daily, especially on weekends

Drinks per occasion?
4-6 beers on weeknights, 8-10 on weekends

Concerns about drinking?
Yes - know it's gotten worse since divorce, using it to cope with stress and loneliness

Have you used recreational drugs in the past year?
Marijuana occasionally (2-3 times per month), used cocaine during marriage but stopped after DUI

Substance use history?
Started drinking heavily in early 20s, was worse during marriage (wife also drank heavily), got DUI during separation, trying to cut back but struggling

FAMILY HISTORY
Family mental health history?
Father had depression and alcoholism (died age 58 from liver disease), mother has anxiety, brother has PTSD from military service

Family substance use history?
Father was alcoholic, uncle on mother's side had drug problems

TRAUMA HISTORY
Childhood trauma?
Witnessed significant domestic violence between parents (father would get drunk and violent), felt responsible for protecting younger siblings, moved around a lot due to financial instability

Adult trauma?
Work injury in 2018 (fell from forklift, chronic back pain since), emotionally abusive marriage, contentious divorce, lost custody battle for primary placement of daughters

WORK/DAILY FUNCTIONING
How is work affected by symptoms?
Calling in sick more often (used 8 sick days in past 3 months), trouble concentrating on tasks, irritable with coworkers, worried about losing job

How are relationships affected?
Divorced, limited contact with daughters (hurts deeply), pushed away friends, arguing with sister more, isolated and lonely

How is self-care affected?
Not eating regularly, sleep is terrible (3-4 hours per night), apartment is messy, not exercising, drinking too much, smoking more

HOBBIES & INTERESTS (BEFORE SYMPTOMS)
Used to enjoy:
- Coaching daughters' soccer team
- Working on cars (had old Mustang project car, had to sell during divorce)
- Fishing with friends
- Playing guitar

Now:
Don't do any of these anymore, no motivation, just work and drink

GOALS FOR TREATMENT
1. Stop feeling so angry and depressed all the time
2. Get my drinking under control before I lose my job or get another DUI
3. Be a better father - want my daughters to see me as stable and healthy
4. Deal with what happened in my childhood and marriage
5. Sleep better and have energy again

STRENGTHS
- Hard worker, good work ethic despite current struggles
- Love my daughters deeply, want to be better for them
- Sister is supportive
- Recognizing I need help (took courage to come here)
- Physically strong despite back pain
- Good at problem-solving when not overwhelmed

familyHistory.mentalHealth: Father: depression and alcoholism (died age 58), Mother: anxiety, Brother: PTSD

traumaHistory.childhood: Witnessed domestic violence, protected siblings, financial instability
traumaHistory.adult: Work injury 2018, emotionally abusive marriage, contentious divorce, custody loss

clinical_intake.qaText:
=== CLINICAL INTAKE RESPONSES ===
Generated: 11/04/2025, 2:30:00 PM

## CHIEF COMPLAINT
Q: What brings you in today? (Chief complaint)
A: Everything fell apart after my divorce. I'm drinking too much, can't sleep, angry all the time. My daughters deserve a better dad than what I've been lately.

## CURRENT SYMPTOMS & IMPACT
Q: How are symptoms impacting your work/school?
A: Severe impact - called in sick 8 times in 3 months, trouble concentrating, irritable with coworkers, worried about losing job

Q: How are symptoms impacting your relationships?
A: Severe impact - divorced, limited time with daughters, pushed away friends, arguing with sister, very isolated

Q: How are symptoms impacting your self-care?
A: Severe impact - not eating regularly, sleeping 3-4 hours, apartment messy, drinking daily, smoking more

Q: How are symptoms impacting your social life?
A: Severe impact - completely isolated, no friends, don't do hobbies anymore, just work and drink

Q: Current stress level (1-10)?
A: 9/10

Q: How would you rate your sleep quality?
A: Very poor - 3-4 hours per night, wake up multiple times, racing thoughts about divorce and daughters

Q: How many days have you missed from work/school in the past month?
A: 3 days

## DAILY LIFE & SELF-CARE
Q: How structured is your daily routine?
A: Very unstructured - work schedule is only consistent thing, everything else is chaotic

Q: What self-care challenges are you facing?
A: Not eating regular meals (maybe once a day), no exercise since back injury, apartment is cluttered and dirty, personal hygiene suffering some days, drinking to cope every night

Q: Describe your typical sleep schedule
A: Try to sleep around midnight, wake up 2-3am and can't fall back asleep, thoughts racing about divorce and daughters, get up exhausted around 6am for work

Q: How do you cope with difficult emotions currently?
A: Drinking, smoking, isolating myself, sometimes punch walls when really angry (never hurt anyone)

## GOALS & STRENGTHS
Q: What are your top 3 treatment goals?
A: Get drinking under control before I lose my job or get another DUI, be a better father for my daughters, stop feeling so angry and depressed all the time

Q: What personal strengths can you build on?
A: Hard worker even when struggling, love my daughters more than anything, sister supports me, I know I need help and came here

Q: On a scale of 1-10, how motivated are you for change?
A: 8/10 - I'm scared of losing everything, especially my daughters

Q: What has prevented you from getting help before?
A: Thought I could handle it myself, stigma about therapy (didn't grow up with that being okay), cost, didn't think I deserved help

## DIAGNOSES
Diagnosis 1:
Q: Diagnosis code (ICD-10/DSM-5)
A: F33.2

Q: Diagnosis description
A: Major Depressive Disorder, Severe

Diagnosis 2:
Q: Diagnosis code (ICD-10/DSM-5)
A: F43.10

Q: Diagnosis description
A: Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder

Diagnosis 3:
Q: Diagnosis code (ICD-10/DSM-5)
A: F10.20

Q: Diagnosis description
A: Alcohol Use Disorder, Severe

## TREATMENT HISTORY
Treatment 1:
Q: Type of treatment
A: Mental Health (tried Zoloft 6 months, didn't complete treatment, stopped on own)

Treatment 2:
Q: Type of treatment
A: Substance Use (completed DUI classes and probation, but no formal SUD treatment)

## MEDICATIONS (CLINICIAN-VERIFIED)
Q: Current medications (clinician-verified)
A: Lisinopril 10mg daily (hypertension), Ibuprofen 800mg PRN (chronic back pain)

Q: Previously trialed psychiatric medications
A: Zoloft (sertraline) 50mg for 6 months - patient reports "didn't feel like it was working" and discontinued on his own without tapering. Trazodone 50mg for sleep for 3 months - discontinued due to morning grogginess that interfered with work functioning.

## MENTAL STATUS EXAMINATION
Q: Appearance and presentation
A: Casually dressed in work clothes (Amazon uniform), appears slightly older than stated age, poor grooming (unshaven, disheveled hair), appears fatigued

Q: Behavior and activity level
A: Cooperative but guarded initially, fidgeting with hands, poor eye contact, becomes tearful when discussing daughters

Q: Speech pattern and quality
A: Normal rate and volume, but monotone affect in voice, occasional long pauses before answering emotionally difficult questions

Q: Stated mood
A: "Depressed, angry, exhausted"

Q: Observed affect
A: Constricted and dysphoric, briefly tearful when discussing children, flattened overall with occasional flashes of irritability

Q: Thought process/organization
A: Linear and goal-directed, no flight of ideas, coherent but occasionally tangential when discussing trauma history

Q: Thought content
A: Denies current suicidal ideation but endorses passive thoughts 6 months ago ("thought everyone would be better off without me"), no current plan or intent. Denies homicidal ideation but acknowledges anger control issues ("I punch walls, never people"). Significant guilt about divorce and impact on daughters. Rumination about past mistakes.

Q: Perceptual disturbances (hallucinations/illusions)
A: Denies hallucinations. Reports occasional intrusive memories/flashbacks of childhood domestic violence and work injury. Hypervigilance noted ("always waiting for something bad to happen").

Q: Cognitive functioning and orientation
A: Alert and oriented x4 (person, place, time, situation). Attention somewhat impaired by depressive symptoms and sleep deprivation. Memory appears intact for recent and remote events. Concentration impaired - reports difficulty at work with multi-step tasks.

Q: Level of insight
A: Fair to good - recognizes he needs help, acknowledges drinking is problematic, understands connection between childhood trauma and current struggles, motivated to change for daughters

Q: Quality of judgment
A: Currently fair - seeking treatment is positive, but recent judgment impaired by substance use (DUI 14 months ago, continued heavy drinking despite consequences). Understands risks but struggles to implement changes.

Q: Clinical Impressions
A: Patient presents with severe depression complicated by untreated PTSD from childhood trauma and recent life stressors, alongside severe alcohol use disorder that patient is using as maladaptive coping mechanism. The interplay between these conditions is significant - childhood domestic violence exposure has created trauma response patterns that are triggered by his own divorce and family disruption. His alcohol use, while initially providing temporary relief from depression and PTSD symptoms, is now exacerbating his mental health decline and creating additional stressors (DUI, work performance issues, financial strain). Assessment scores confirm severe depression (PHQ-9: 21), moderate-to-severe PTSD symptoms (PCL-5: 52), and severe alcohol use disorder (AUDIT: 28). High ACE score (6/10) indicates significant childhood adversity contributing to current presentation. Patient's insight and motivation are protective factors, as is his deep love for his daughters and relationship with supportive sister. Immediate risks include job loss, another DUI, worsening physical health from alcohol use, and potential suicide risk if depression continues to worsen. Patient requires integrated treatment addressing mental health and substance use simultaneously.

Q: Clinical Recommendations
A: Recommend comprehensive integrated treatment approach including: 1) Psychiatric evaluation for medication management - consider SSRI trial (patient discontinued Zoloft prematurely, may benefit from adequate trial at therapeutic dose with proper monitoring) and possible adjunct medication for sleep given severe insomnia, 2) Individual trauma-focused therapy (EMDR or CPT) to address childhood trauma and PTSD symptoms, 3) Substance use treatment - recommend intensive outpatient program (IOP) given severity of alcohol use disorder and need for structured support, include relapse prevention planning, 4) Case management for care coordination and resource connection, 5) Possible short-term medical leave from work to focus on stabilization if symptoms continue to impair functioning, 6) Safety planning given past suicidal ideation - establish crisis resources and check-ins, 7) Encourage engagement with peer support (AA or SMART Recovery) for substance use recovery, 8) Family therapy or parenting support to improve relationship with daughters and address guilt. Priority is stabilizing substance use and depression to prevent further deterioration and potential safety crisis.

=== END OF CLINICAL INTAKE ===

phq9.title: PHQ-9 (Patient Health Questionnaire-9)

responses.question: Little interest or pleasure in doing things
Feeling down, depressed, or hopeless
Trouble falling/staying asleep, or sleeping too much
Feeling tired or having little energy
Poor appetite or overeating
Feeling bad about yourself - or that you are a failure or have let yourself or your family down
Trouble concentrating on things, such as reading the newspaper or watching television
Moving or speaking so slowly that other people could have noticed, or the opposite - being so fidgety or restless that you have been moving around a lot more than usual
Thoughts that you would be better off dead, or of hurting yourself in some way

phq9.interpretation: Score of 21 indicates severe depression. Patient endorses nearly daily anhedonia, depressed mood, insomnia, fatigue, guilt/worthlessness, with several days of passive suicidal ideation. Immediate clinical attention warranted.

gad7.title: GAD-7 (Generalized Anxiety Disorder-7)

responses.question: Feeling nervous, anxious, or on edge
Not being able to stop or control worrying
Worrying too much about different things
Trouble relaxing
Being so restless that it's hard to sit still
Becoming easily annoyed or irritable
Feeling afraid as if something awful might happen

gad7.interpretation: Score of 14 indicates moderate anxiety. Patient reports frequent worry, difficulty relaxing, and significant irritability. Anxiety likely related to PTSD hypervigilance and current life stressors.

ace.title: ACE (Adverse Childhood Experiences)

responses.question: Did a parent or other adult in the household often or very often swear at you, insult you, put you down, or humiliate you?
Did a parent or other adult in the household often or very often push, grab, slap, or throw something at you, or ever hit you so hard that you had marks or were injured?
Did an adult or person at least 5 years older than you ever touch or fondle you or have you touch their body in a sexual way, or attempt or actually have oral, anal, or vaginal intercourse with you?
Did you often or very often feel that no one in your family loved you or thought you were important or special?
Did you often or very often feel that your family didn't look out for each other, feel close to each other, or support each other?
Were your parents ever separated or divorced?

Was your mother or stepmother often or very often pushed, grabbed, slapped, or had something thrown at her, or sometimes, often, or very often kicked, bitten, hit with a fist, or hit with something hard?
Did you live with anyone who was a problem drinker or alcoholic, or who used street drugs?
Was a household member depressed or mentally ill, or did a household member attempt suicide?
Did a household member go to prison?

ace.interpretation: Score of 6 out of 10 indicates high adverse childhood experiences. Patient endorses emotional abuse, physical abuse, emotional neglect, household dysfunction (domestic violence, substance abuse). ACE scores of 4+ are associated with significantly increased risk for depression, substance use disorders, and PTSD in adulthood. Patient's current presentation is consistent with research on high ACE scores and their long-term mental health impacts.

audit.title: AUDIT (Alcohol Use Disorders Identification Test)
audit.severity: Severe alcohol use disorder - high risk

responses.question: How often do you have a drink containing alcohol?
How many drinks containing alcohol do you have on a typical day when you are drinking?
How often do you have six or more drinks on one occasion?
How often during the last year have you found that you were not able to stop drinking once you had started?
How often during the last year have you failed to do what was normally expected of you because of drinking?
How often during the last year have you needed a first drink in the morning to get yourself going after a heavy drinking session?
How often during the last year have you had a feeling of guilt or remorse after drinking?
How often during the last year have you been unable to remember what happened the night before because of your drinking?
Have you or someone else been injured because of your drinking?
responses.answer: Yes, but not in the last year

responses.question: Has a relative, friend, doctor, or other health care worker been concerned about your drinking or suggested you cut down?

audit.interpretation: Score of 28 indicates severe alcohol use disorder with high risk for alcohol-related harm. Patient reports daily drinking with inability to stop, frequent binge drinking (6+ drinks), daily guilt, weekly blackouts, and negative consequences (work performance, DUI). Morning drinking occasionally present suggesting physical dependence. Sister and healthcare worker have expressed concern. Patient requires comprehensive substance use treatment and medical evaluation for withdrawal risk.

dast10.title: DAST-10 (Drug Abuse Screening Test)
dast10.severity: Low to moderate substance use concerns

responses.question: Have you used drugs other than those required for medical reasons?
responses.answer: Yes - marijuana currently, cocaine in past

responses.question: Do you abuse more than one drug at a time?
responses.answer: No - only marijuana now, stopped cocaine after DUI

responses.question: Are you unable to stop using drugs when you want to?
responses.answer: No - able to stop cocaine, marijuana is occasional

responses.question: Have you ever had blackouts or flashbacks as a result of drug use?
Do you ever feel bad or guilty about your drug use?
responses.answer: Yes - felt guilty about cocaine use during marriage

responses.question: Does your spouse (or parents) ever complain about your involvement with drugs?
responses.answer: Yes - ex-wife complained about cocaine use

responses.question: Have you neglected your family because of your use of drugs?
Have you engaged in illegal activities in order to obtain drugs?
Have you ever experienced withdrawal symptoms (felt sick) when you stopped taking drugs?
Have you had medical problems as a result of your drug use?

dast10.interpretation: Score of 3 indicates low to moderate substance use concerns. Patient reports past cocaine use (discontinued after DUI), current occasional marijuana use (2-3x/month). While current drug use is less problematic than alcohol, history suggests polysubstance use pattern during periods of high stress. Patient demonstrates ability to discontinue substances (cocaine), which is protective factor. Primary substance use concern is severe alcohol use disorder.
